H0.text: Gravity is represented by the string that the student ties around the weight and swings in a circle around her body, with the student standing for the Sun and the weight standing for Earth.

H1.text: Radiation is the string that a student ties around a weight and swings in a circle around her body, with the student representing the Sun and the weight representing Earth.

H2.text: Electricity is represented by the string in the demonstration where a student ties a string around a weight and swings the weight in a circle around her body, with the student standing in the role of the Sun and the weight representing Earth.

H3.text: Magnetism is the string that represents the force keeping the Earth in orbit around the Sun in the model where a student ties a string around a weight and swings it in a circle around her body.

A4.text: Gravity is a fundamental interaction that attracts every object with mass in proportion to their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them.

A5.text: In the case of an object that is swinging around on the end of a rope in a horizontal plane, the centripetal force on the object is supplied by the tension of the rope.

A6.text: When a satellite is in orbit around a planet, gravity is considered to be a centripetal force even though in the case of eccentric orbits, the gravitational force is directed towards the focus, and not towards the instantaneous center of curvature.

A7.text: If the object has enough tangential velocity, it will not fall into the gravitating body but can instead continue to follow the curved trajectory caused by the force indefinitely.

A8.text: The acceleration of a body is equal to the combination of the forces acting on it, divided by its mass.

A9.text: The Sun dominates the system by mass, producing temperatures and densities in its core high enough to sustain nuclear fusion of hydrogen into helium.

A10.text: The fusion of hydrogen into helium inside the Sun's core releases over billions of years energy, which is over even longer times emitted through its outer photosphere.

A11.text: Earth orbits the Sun at an average distance of 149.60 million km (92.96 million mi), or 8.317 light-minutes, in a counterclockwise direction as viewed from above the Northern Hemisphere.

A12.text: Earth's orbital speed averages 29.78 km/s (18.50 mi/s; 107,208.00 km/h; 66,615.96 mph), which is fast enough to cover the planet's diameter in approximately 67 minutes and the distance to the Moon in 6 to 7 hours.

A13.text: Earth's speed through space is about 1 million miles an hour.

A14.text: Without applying force (such as firing a rocket engine), the period and shape of the satellite's orbit will not change.

A15.text: A satellite in a low orbit (or a low part of an elliptical orbit) moves more quickly with respect to the surface of the planet than a satellite in a higher orbit (or a high part of an elliptical orbit), due to the stronger gravitational attraction closer to the planet.
